libshapedraw.animation
Interface Animates<T>

All Known Implementing Classes:
Color, ShapeRotate, ShapeScale, ShapeTranslate, Vector3
public interface Animates<T>

Simple, easy animation for a set of properties on an object.

Calling animateStart/animateStop will take care of setting up and managing an internal Timeline, which will update the properties every 40 milliseconds (25 FPS). This interface pares things down to a few simple method calls.

For more control over the animation, you can set up your own external Timeline instead. When playing an external Timeline, don't use this interface's methods simultaneously. Two Timelines actively updating the same properties will likely result in unexpected behavior.

Method Summary
 Animates<T> animateStart(T toProperties, long durationMs)
          Start a finite animation on this object's properties, gradually changing them to match the specified properties over the specified interval.
 Animates<T> animateStartLoop(T toProperties, boolean reverse, long durationMs)
          Start a looping animating this object's properties, gradually changing them to match the specified properties over the specified interval.
 Animates<T> animateStop()
          If there is an active animation changing this object's properties, stop it abruptly, leaving things in an intermediate state.
 boolean isAnimating()
          Whether the properties are being updated by an active animation.
 

Method Detail

isAnimating

boolean isAnimating()
Whether the properties are being updated by an active animation.

animateStop

Animates<T> animateStop()
If there is an active animation changing this object's properties, stop it abruptly, leaving things in an intermediate state.

After calling this method it is safe to use other methods to modify the properties without being overwritten by the animation.

Returns:
the same object, modified in-place.

animateStart

Animates<T> animateStart(T toProperties,
                         long durationMs)
Start a finite animation on this object's properties, gradually changing them to match the specified properties over the specified interval.

After starting an animation, using any other method that modifies the properties is a bad idea, as the animation will be frequently overwriting them. Either wait for the animation to complete or use animateStop() to halt the animation early.

Parameters:
toProperties - the properties to gradually change to.
durationMs - interval in milliseconds, >= 0.
Returns:
the same object, modified in-place.

animateStartLoop

Animates<T> animateStartLoop(T toProperties,
                             boolean reverse,
                             long durationMs)
Start a looping animating this object's properties, gradually changing them to match the specified properties over the specified interval.

The animation loops indefinitely, going back and forth between the original properties and the specified properties.

After starting an animation, using any other method that modifies the properties is a bad idea, as the animation will be frequently overwriting them. Use animateStop() to halt the animation first.

Parameters:
toProperties - the properties to gradually change to.
reverse - if true, fade back to the original properties each time the animation loops. If false, jump directly back to the original properties each time.
durationMs - interval in milliseconds of each cycle, >= 0.
Returns:
the same object, modified in-place.
